It is not legal to send Paul to Haiti, because he is not a Haitian citizen. This fact is not in dispute. Don‚Äôt take it from me ‚Äî take it from the Haitian Ambassador. 

https://twitter.com/BocchitEdmond/status/1351598852986597385?s=20 QT @BocchitEdmond After many interventions of the @EmbassyOfHaiti Mr Paul Pierrilus was removed from the flight to PAP. We will continue to cooperate with relevant US authorities but within the limit of established principles. Mr Pierrilus isn‚Äôt a Haitian Citizen & thus can‚Äôt be sent to Haiti.

If this story sounds familiar, that‚Äôs because it is. Just two weeks ago, my staff successfully halted Paul‚Äôs deportation at the last second, after ICE failed to provide evidence that his deportation was valid. 

https://www.washingtonpost.com/immigration/in-one-of-its-last-acts-trump-administration-tried-to-deport-man-to-haiti-who-has-never-been-there/2021/01/20/738d88e4-5b49-11eb-a976-bad6431e03e2_story.html

At 3am, my staff woke up to an urgent call. Suddenly, and in the dead of night, ICE was set to deport Rockland County‚Äôs beloved Paul Pierrilus to Haiti, a country where he has never been. 

And there was nothing we could do to stop it.

@mdad8200 Agree.  But that doesn't mean there won't be specific individuals who are hurt in that transition.  Every step change in our energy system has increased productivity and created more jobs.  And every one has taken time, during which real lives were disrupted.

Good.

https://www.eenews.net/stories/1063724017
But we need to recognize the inherently short term nature of the current labor spike.  That is ultimately the root cause of the stresses in this story.  /fin
That is a good thing.  Labor productivity growth is, after all, the only long term source of GDP growth.

But the core issue here derives from the fact that old, dirty energy sources are really OPERATING labor intensive.  New clean sources require a surge in construction jobs but much less operating labor.

To be clear, there is a lot more in this story as well, and I wish we'd stop talking about highly technical jobs as an alternative to being a barista.  It's an extremely patronizing view of the American worker.

This is worth the read.  It is the natural result of the fact that a transition to clean energy is a huge labor productivity enhancer.  (Eg, many more MWH per hour of labor.)  That is good for the economy but will create temporary labor dislocations.

Https://www.eenews.net/stories/1063722919
